questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of feeling tired, dry skin, and recent weight gain despite no changes in her diet. She also notes experiencing constipation and increased sensitivity to cold. On physical examination, her thyroid gland is enlarged but non-tender, and her reflexes are slow. Laboratory tests reveal an elevated TSH level and low free T4. An ultrasound of the thyroid shows a diffusely enlarged gland with heterogeneous echotexture. A biopsy of the thyroid is performed, and the histology is shown. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder and the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. The condition is characterized by symptoms such as fatigue, weight gain, dry skin, constipation, and increased sensitivity to cold, which are all signs of hypothyroidism. The physical exam typically reveals an enlarged thyroid gland, which may feel firm but is usually non-tender. The ultrasound findings of a diffusely enlarged thyroid with heterogeneous texture further support the diagnosis. Histologically, Hashimoto thyroiditis shows lymphocytic infiltration, germinal center formation, and Hurthle cell changes.
  • • Pathophysiology : In Hashimoto thyroiditis, the immune system mistakenly attacks the thyroid gland, leading to chronic inflammation and gradual thyroid destruction. This autoimmune process is mediated by autoantibodies against thyroid peroxidase (TPO) and thyroglobulin, resulting in a gradual decline in thyroid hormone production.
  • • Pathophysiology
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Subacute thyroiditis: This option is incorrect because subacute thyroiditis, often following a viral illness, typically presents with a painful, tender thyroid gland. Patients may initially experience hyperthyroidism due to thyroid inflammation and release of stored hormones, followed by a period of hypothyroidism. Histology would show granulomatous inflammation, not the lymphocytic infiltration seen in Hashimoto thyroiditis.
  • • Option B. Subacute thyroiditis:
  • • Option C. Riedel thyroiditis: This option is incorrect because Riedel thyroiditis is a rare condition characterized by fibrous replacement of thyroid tissue, leading to a hard, fixed thyroid mass. Symptoms are typically more mechanical, such as compression of surrounding structures, and histology shows dense fibrosis without the characteristic lymphocytic infiltration seen in Hashimoto thyroiditis.
  • • Option C. Riedel thyroiditis:
  • • Option D. Toxic multinodular goiter: This option is incorrect as toxic multinodular goiter usually presents with symptoms of hyperthyroidism, including weight loss, palpitations, and heat intolerance. Ultrasound would show a nodular thyroid, and histology would demonstrate nodules of varying sizes rather than diffuse lymphocytic infiltration.
  • • Option D. Toxic multinodular goiter:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder and the leading cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient regions. It presents with symptoms of hypothyroidism, an enlarged thyroid, and characteristic histological findings of lymphocytic infiltration and Hurthle cells. Proper recognition of clinical, laboratory, and imaging findings is essential for diagnosis and management

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about lupus nephritis in pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Immunosuppression can be continued during pregnancy

options.label: B
options.text: Pregnancy to be planned once the disease has been quiescent for at least 6 months and there is no evidence of renal dysfunction

options.label: C
options.text: High dose corticosteroids for lupus flare in pregnancy is safe

options.label: D
options.text: Ecospirin, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, azathioprine are safe in pregnancy

questions.correct_answer: D. Ecospirin, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, azathioprine are safe in pregnancy
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ecospirin, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, azathioprine are safe in pregnancy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • SLE is a chronic autoimmune disorder involving the multisystem. It affects young women of childbearing age. The renal involvement of the disease can manifest in the form of active lupus nephritis or flare-ups during pregnancy. It can lead to preterm births, preeclampsia, and pregnancy loss while the infant can suffer from neonatal lupus and heart block. Management includes Preconceptionally counseling: Conception during a period of quiescence for at least 6 months determines a successful outcome. Stable remission of renal disease for at least 6 months before conception is recommended. Corticosteroids are useful during episodes of lupus flare and can be used safely in pregnancy. Immunosuppressants such as azathioprine can be continued during pregnancy. It may be used in case of severe SLE Hydroxychloroquine is found to be the best for maintenance and is safe in pregnancy. It can prevent the need for prolonged corticosteroid therapy. Methotrexate and cyclophosphamide are teratogenic and hence they are not safe during pregnancy.
  • • SLE is a chronic autoimmune disorder involving the multisystem. It affects young women of childbearing age. The renal involvement of the disease can manifest in the form of active lupus nephritis or flare-ups during pregnancy.
  • • It can lead to preterm births, preeclampsia, and pregnancy loss while the infant can suffer from neonatal lupus and heart block.
  • • Management includes
  • • Preconceptionally counseling: Conception during a period of quiescence for at least 6 months determines a successful outcome. Stable remission of renal disease for at least 6 months before conception is recommended.
  • • Corticosteroids are useful during episodes of lupus flare and can be used safely in pregnancy.
  • • Immunosuppressants such as azathioprine can be continued during pregnancy. It may be used in case of severe SLE
  • • Hydroxychloroquine is found to be the best for maintenance and is safe in pregnancy. It can prevent the need for prolonged corticosteroid therapy.
  • • Methotrexate and cyclophosphamide are teratogenic and hence they are not safe during pregnancy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Immunosuppression can be continued during pregnancy : Correct. Medications like azathioprine can be continued under medical guidance, while others are used cautiously.
  • • Option A. Immunosuppression can be continued during pregnancy
  • • Option B. Pregnancy to be planned once the disease has been quiescent for at least 6 months and there is no evidence of renal dysfunction : Correct. Quiescence of the disease and stable renal function are crucial for a successful pregnancy outcome.
  • • Option B. Pregnancy to be planned once the disease has been quiescent for at least 6 months and there is no evidence of renal dysfunction
  • • Option C. High dose corticosteroids for lupus flare in pregnancy is safe : Correct. High doses of corticosteroids can be used during a lupus flare, but must be carefully monitored.
  • • Option C. High dose corticosteroids for lupus flare in pregnancy is safe

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methotrexate and cyclophosphamide are not safe during pregnancy for managing lupus nephritis; corticosteroids and azathioprine are safer options.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 2895, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to the clinic with a painless, progressively enlarging mass in his right testicle, noticed over the past six months. He denies any history of trauma, infection, or systemic symptoms. On physical examination, a firm, non-tender testicular mass is palpated, which does not transilluminate. Tumor markers, including alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG), are within normal limits. Scrotal ultrasound reveals a solid, hypoechoic lesion within the testis. An orchidectomy is performed, and histopathological analysis of the specimen is shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Seminomas are the most common type of testicular germ cell tumors in adult men, often presenting as painless, firm testicular masses. Morphologically, seminomas are well-circumscribed, pale, gray-white, and homogeneous masses with a fleshy and lobulated cut surface, typically without hemorrhage or necrosis. Histologically, they consist of sheets of large, uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and distinct cell borders. The nuclei are centrally located, large, and round with prominent nucleoli. Minimal mitotic activity and a lack of significant inflammatory infiltrate, such as lymphocytes or syncytiotrophoblast cells, are typical features, which help distinguish seminomas from more aggressive germ cell tumors.
  • • Pathophysiology : Seminomas arise from germ cells and exhibit relatively indolent growth compared to other testicular tumors. Their uniform histological appearance and response to radiation and chemotherapy contribute to an excellent prognosis when detected early.
  • • Pathophysiology
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Embryonal carcinoma: This option is incorrect because embryonal carcinoma is a more aggressive, poorly differentiated germ cell tumor often associated with elevated tumor markers such as AFP or β-hCG. Histologically, it displays a more disorganized architecture with high mitotic activity, pleomorphic cells, and areas of hemorrhage and necrosis, contrasting with the orderly appearance of seminomas.
  • • Option B. Embryonal carcinoma:
  • • Option C. Spermatocytic tumor: This option is incorrect as spermatocytic tumors are rare testicular tumors typically occurring in older men. They have a different histological appearance characterized by a mix of small, medium, and large cells without the clear cytoplasm seen in seminomas. They are generally slow-growing and do not show the same aggressive behavior as seminomas.
  • • Option C. Spermatocytic tumor:
  • • Option D. Testicular lymphoma: This option is incorrect because testicular lymphoma is the most common testicular tumor in older men but is very rare in younger adults. It usually presents with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma histology, showing sheets of lymphoid cells rather than the large, clear cells characteristic of seminomas.
  • • Option D. Testicular lymphoma:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Seminomas are the most common testicular germ cell tumors in men, presenting as painless masses with characteristic histological features of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm, prominent nucleoli, and minimal inflammatory infiltrates. Recognizing the typical morphological and histological features of seminomas aids in accurate diagnosis and management, contributing to a favorable prognosis with appropriate treatment.

A transverse lie is more commonly associated with an arcuate or sub-septate uterus, rather than uterus didelphys. Uterus didelphys usually has a better reproductive outcome compared to other uterine anomalies, though it still presents with certain risks.
  • • Transverse lie:
  • • Other options:

Endometriosis: Endometriosis can occur in patients with uterus didelphys, particularly in the rare variant known as OHVIRA syndrome (Obstructed Hemi Vagina with Ipsilateral Renal Agenesis), where menstrual blood can become trapped, leading to retrograde menstruation and endometriosis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic by her parents due to a painless swelling on the right side of her neck that has gradually increased in size over the past six months. The swelling is firm, non-tender, and located laterally without transillumination. On further examination, the child has several hyperpigmented macules and freckling noted in the axillary and inguinal regions. She has no history of trauma, fever, or significant weight loss. Based on her clinical presentation and examination findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • The patient's presentation suggests a neural tumor, specifically a neurofibroma, which is commonly associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). Key characteristics include a painless lateral neck mass in a pediatric patient, the non-tender nature of the mass, and the presence of café-au-lait spots and freckling in axillary and inguinal regions. Neurofibromas are benign nerve sheath tumors that appear as firm, rubbery masses and are often associated with NF1, a genetic condition marked by multiple neural tumors, café-au-lait macules, and axillary/inguinal freckling.
  • • Clinical Characteristics :
  • • Clinical Characteristics
  • • Presence of a painless, lateral neck mass in a pediatric patient. The mass is firm and non-tender. Associated with skin manifestations such as freckles and hyperpigmented patches (café-au-lait spots), often seen in NF1.
  • • Presence of a painless, lateral neck mass in a pediatric patient.
  • • The mass is firm and non-tender.
  • • Associated with skin manifestations such as freckles and hyperpigmented patches (café-au-lait spots), often seen in NF1.
  • • Pathophysiology : Neurofibromas in NF1 arise due to mutations in the NF1 gene on chromosome 17, which leads to a loss of function of neurofibromin, a tumor suppressor protein. This results in uncontrolled cell growth, leading to the formation of neurofibromas and other characteristic lesions of NF1.
  • • Pathophysiology
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Lipoblastoma: This option is incorrect because lipoblastomas are benign soft tissue tumors derived from embryonic fat, commonly presenting as soft, lobulated masses. They lack the firm texture and neural association seen in neurofibromas and are not linked to café-au-lait spots or characteristic freckling.
  • • Option B. Lipoblastoma:
  • • Option C. Branchial cleft cyst: This option is incorrect as branchial cleft cysts are congenital neck masses that are soft, fluctuant, and often become infected, presenting with pain and drainage. They are not associated with systemic findings such as freckles or café-au-lait spots and lack the typical features of neural tumors.
  • • Option C. Branchial cleft cyst:
  • • Option D. Reactive lymphadenopathy: This option is incorrect because reactive lymphadenopathy typically presents as tender, mobile lymph nodes often associated with recent infections. It is not characterized by persistent, firm, painless masses or associated skin findings seen in NF1.
  • • Option D. Reactive lymphadenopathy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Neural tumors, particularly neurofibromas, are commonly seen in neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), a genetic disorder presenting with painless, firm masses and associated skin findings such as café-au-lait spots and axillary freckling. Early recognition of these features is essential for diagnosing NF1 and managing the potential complications associated with neural tumors

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, a habitual smoker, visits the hospital. He describes experiencing recurring pain in his thighs and buttocks when he walks, particularly noticeable after covering a distance of approximately 500 meters. What could be a plausible diagnosis for his symptoms?(NEET PG 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery

options.label: D
options.text: Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery

questions.correct_answer: B. Arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of arterial disease with intermittent claudication due to aortoiliac occlusion. Claudication pain in the buttocks and thighs, particularly during walking, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease, also known as Leriche syndrome in more severe cases if associated with impotence. The aortoiliac arteries are major blood vessels that supply the lower half of the body. Blockages in these arteries can lead to pain in the buttocks, thighs, or hips upon exertion. The claudication pain in the buttocks or thighs, as described by the patient, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease. Therefore, this is the most plausible diagnosis given the patient's symptoms.
  • • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of arterial disease with intermittent claudication due to aortoiliac occlusion. Claudication pain in the buttocks and thighs, particularly during walking, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease, also known as Leriche syndrome in more severe cases if associated with impotence.
  • • The aortoiliac arteries are major blood vessels that supply the lower half of the body. Blockages in these arteries can lead to pain in the buttocks, thighs, or hips upon exertion. The claudication pain in the buttocks or thighs, as described by the patient, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease. Therefore, this is the most plausible diagnosis given the patient's symptoms.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery: This type of arterial disease would involve blockage in the superficial femoral artery, which runs through the thigh. Patients with this condition typically experience claudication pain in the calf muscles because the superficial femoral artery primarily supplies the calf muscles.
  • • Option A. Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery:
  • • Option C. Femoral venous insufficiency: Femoral venous insufficiency involves issues with the veins, not the arteries. This condition typically leads to symptoms like leg swelling, varicose veins, and skin changes, but it does not cause claudication or pain upon walking specific distances.

questions.text: In a suspected case of cholangitis in a 47-year-old woman, what other component besides abdominal pain does not comprise Reynold's pentad? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cholangitis is an infection of the common bile duct caused by obstruction and increased pressure due to CBD stones. The classical triad of cholangitis (Charcot) is fever, right upper quadrant pain, and jaundice. If left untreated, cholangitis can progress to Reynold's pentad with hypotension and altered mental status due to sepsis. Abdominal ultrasound is used to diagnose biliary stones and bile duct dilatations in cholangitis. Treatment for cholangitis includes broad-spectrum antibiotics, rehydration, and biliary drainage using endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP). Biliary stones are the primary cause of cholangitis and can be removed by endoscopic sphincterotomy during ERCP.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Cervical spine stabilization, intubation, IV cannulation, CECT is the correct sequence of management in a patient who presents to the casualty with an RTA.
  • ➤ The steps in Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) include the following: primary survey with simultaneous resuscitation, secondary survey, and definitive care.
  • ➤ The ABCDE of trauma care include Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate), Breathing and ventilation assessment, Circulation assessment, Disability assessment, and Exposure, with environmental control. During airway securing, cervical spine should be stabilised first (with a hard cervical collar) prior to attempting any manoeuvres like endotracheal intubation.
  • ➤ Adjuncts to the primary survey include blood tests, ECG, pulse oximetry, urinary and gastric catheters, and radiographs.
  • ➤ Specialized imaging like CECT should be considered after the secondary survey and only when the patient is stable after initial resuscitation.

  • ➤ Initial treatment for burns includes cleaning the burnt areas and removing loose dead skin. Blisters are de-roofed and an appropriate dressing is applied.
  • ➤ Biological dressing (collagen dressings, amniotic membrane, etc.) is the preferred dressing material, especially in partial thickness burns.
  • ➤ If this is not available then a non-adhesive dressing like paraffin gauze impregnated with silver sulfadiazine (SSD) cream, colloidal silver, ionic silver cream, or silver nitrate cream may be applied. Since increased resistance to SSD has recently emerged, it should be used judiciously and reserved for deep dermal, full thickness, infected, and old neglected burns.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a rollover car accident. She is conscious but in significant pain, with vital signs showing a blood pressure of 88/50 mmHg, a heart rate of 115 beats per minute, and shallow respirations. As part of the primary survey, the trauma team performs imaging to quickly assess her condition. Which of the following statements about imaging in the primary survey of trauma patients is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: FAST ultrasound is a rapid tool for detecting internal bleeding in trauma patients.

options.label: B
options.text: Chest X-ray is used to identify critical chest injuries such as pneumothorax or hemothorax.

options.label: C
options.text: Pelvic X-ray is mandatory during the primary survey for all trauma patients.

options.label: D
options.text: Whole-body CT scans are typically performed once the patient is stabilized for a comprehensive evaluation.

questions.correct_answer: C. Pelvic X-ray is mandatory during the primary survey for all trauma patients.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Pelvic X-rays are frequently utilized in trauma cases to detect fractures that could lead to significant bleeding. However, they are not mandatory for every trauma patient during the primary survey. The decision to perform a pelvic X-ray is based on clinical evaluation, mechanism of injury, and signs of hemodynamic instability suggestive of pelvic trauma. The primary survey focuses on quickly identifying life-threatening conditions using imaging tools like FAST ultrasound and chest X-rays, reserving pelvic X-rays for patients with specific indications rather than as a routine for all.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. FAST ultrasound is a rapid tool for detecting internal bleeding in trauma patients: This statement is true. The FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) exam is a critical part of the primary survey, used to detect free fluid in the chest, abdomen, or pelvis, indicating internal bleeding, and guiding urgent management decisions.
  • • Option A. FAST ultrasound is a rapid tool for detecting internal bleeding in trauma patients:
  • • Option B. Chest X-ray is used to identify critical chest injuries such as pneumothorax or hemothorax: This statement is true. Chest X-rays are commonly performed during the primary survey to rapidly assess for life-threatening thoracic injuries like pneumothorax, hemothorax, and rib fractures, which require immediate attention.
  • • Option B. Chest X-ray is used to identify critical chest injuries such as pneumothorax or hemothorax:
  • • Option D. Whole-body CT scans are typically performed once the patient is stabilized for a comprehensive evaluation: This statement is true. Whole-body CT scans provide a detailed evaluation of trauma patients but are usually reserved for the secondary survey once the patient is stable, due to the time required and the need for patient immobility during the scan.
  • • Option D. Whole-body CT scans are typically performed once the patient is stabilized for a comprehensive evaluation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ During the primary survey in trauma patients, imaging is focused on rapid identification of life-threatening conditions using tools like FAST ultrasound and chest X-rays. Pelvic X-rays are not routinely required for all trauma patients and should be performed based on clinical suspicion of pelvic injury, highlighting the need for selective and targeted imaging in trauma management.

  • ➤ The length of tube to be inserted is calculated by measuring the distance between nose-tip of ear lobule-xiphoid (N-E-X rule).

questions.text: Which of these is/are included as a part of primary survey in trauma? (multiple correct combinations) (INICET MAY 2024) A. Endotracheal intubation B. Chest X-ray C. Plain CT D. ICD insertion

options.label: C
options.text: A, B and D are correct

questions.correct_answer: C. A, B and D are correct
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A, B and D are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the primary survey of a trauma patient, life-saving interventions like ET intubation, bedside chest X-ray, and ICD insertion are performed to stabilize the patient. A CT scan is not part of this immediate assessment and is reserved for stable patients.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male underwent a bilateral laparoscopic hernia repair for inguinal hernia. Postoperatively, he complained of pain in the right thigh. Which of the following nerve entrapment leads to this symptom? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.correct_answer: D. Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Meralgia paresthetica, characterized by pain in the thigh, is commonly due to entrapment of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, especially following laparoscopic hernia repair. Proper placement of mesh and tacks during surgery is crucial to avoid this nerve injury.

questions.text: Size cut off for operating an abdominal aortic aneurysm is greater than? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 5.5 cm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ AAA refers to an enlargement or ballooning of the abdominal aorta. It can be a potentially life-threatening condition if it ruptures.
  • ➤ The size of the AAA is a crucial factor in determining the need for surgical intervention. The risk of rupture increases significantly as the size of the aneurysm grows.
  • ➤ An asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm in an otherwise fit patient is considered for repair if >55 mm in diameter (measured by ultrasonography). The annual incidence of rupture rises from 1% or less in aneurysms that are <55 mm in diameter to a significant level of nearly 25%, in those that are 70 mm in diameter.
  • ➤ As open elective surgery (transabdominal) carries a 5% mortality rate, the balance is in favor of elective operation once the maximum diameter is >55 mm.
  • ➤ 6 monthly follow-up ultrasonographic surveillance is indicated for asymptomatic aneurysms <55 mm in diameter.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented to the dermatologist with a small lesion on her right nasolabial fold. Upon examination, the dermatologist noted a 0.4-cm nodule with a smooth surface and well-defined borders. The nodule was located on the upper forehead, just above the eyebrows. It was excised and a pathological examination was done. The image is given below. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Basal cell carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Basal cell carcinoma is the most common type of skin cancer and is typically found in sun-exposed areas. It appears as a pearly nodule with visible blood vessels and can cause significant local destruction if left untreated. Mohs micrographic surgery is an effective treatment, particularly for tumors in cosmetically sensitive areas.
  • ➤ Basal cell carcinoma is the most common type of skin cancer and is typically found in sun-exposed areas.
  • ➤ It appears as a pearly nodule with visible blood vessels and can cause significant local destruction if left untreated.
  • ➤ Mohs micrographic surgery is an effective treatment, particularly for tumors in cosmetically sensitive areas.

questions.text: Which of the following is the usual cause of thyroid storm in thyroidectomy? (AIIMS NOV 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Rough handling of thyroid during surgery

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Inadequate patient preparation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A thyroid storm, also known as thyrotoxic crisis, is a rare but life-threatening medical emergency that occurs in individuals with severe hyperthyroidism. Hyperthyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland produces an excessive amount of thyroid hormones, primarily thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3). In a thyroid storm, these hormone levels become dangerously elevated, leading to a wide range of symptoms and complications.
  • ➤ Symptoms of a thyroid storm may include:
  • ➤ High fever Rapid and irregular heartbeat (tachycardia) Elevated blood pressure Extreme agitation and restlessness Profuse sweating Tremors and shaking Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea Delirium or confusion Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes) Coma (in severe cases)
  • ➤ High fever
  • ➤ Rapid and irregular heartbeat (tachycardia)
  • ➤ Elevated blood pressure
  • ➤ Extreme agitation and restlessness
  • ➤ Profuse sweating
  • ➤ Tremors and shaking
  • ➤ Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea
  • ➤ Delirium or confusion
  • ➤ Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
  • ➤ Coma (in severe cases)
  • ➤ Thyroid storms can be triggered by various factors, such as surgery, infection, trauma, or medication changes in individuals with underlying hyperthyroidism. The condition is more common in people with Graves' disease, a common cause of hyperthyroidism.
  • ➤ Treatment of a thyroid storm is a medical emergency and typically involves a combination of interventions to rapidly lower thyroid hormone levels, control symptoms, and support vital organ function.
  • ➤ The usual cause of thyroid storm in thyroidectomy is inadequate patient preparation before surgery. Thus, patient preparation pre-operatively involves ensuring a euthyroid state.
